messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: katana vs wakizashi
messages.msgSnippet: Gordon, Thanks for the input - I was thinkin maybe that funky shape on part of it might have started out as a kogai... I guess I ll just have to keep looking
messages.messageBody:
Gordon,

Thanks for the input - I was thinkin' maybe that funky shape on part of
it might have started out as a kogai...
I guess I'll just have to keep looking for more pre edo fittings to
study :-)

thx,

rkg
(Richard George)

>Hi Richard,
>
>Looks like a kozuka-ana to me. The shape of the ana would be more indicative
>of a kogai rather than the size. Some early stuff with what can be taken as
>ubu-ana can be either very large or very small. Ko-Mino kogai come in a wild
>variety of sizes including pencil thin ones.
>
>Gordon
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Richard George [mailto:rkg@...]
> Sent: Friday, April 25, 2003 2:18 PM
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: katana vs wakizashi
>
>
> Hi,
>
> Could it be that a some of these "uchigatana sized" tsuba got flipped
> over and the kogai ana used for kozuka ana?
>
> I have one piece where the side where most of the banging is around the
> nakago ana would iply the hitsu ana was for a kozuka, but
> from the shape the ana itself kind of looks like it might have been for
> a kogai, and there is some banging on the other side
> that looks like they originally did on these pieces - check out:
>
> http://home.teleport.com/~rkg/photos/tsuba/tosho3_front_small.JPG
> http://home.teleport.com/~rkg/photos/tsuba/tosho3_back_small.JPG
>
> Another couple of explanations I'd posit is that perhaps there were a
> LOT more uchigatana
> that weren't katana length or that perhaps people were turning their
> uchigatana into
> wakizashi via shortening when it became the rage to have a
> wakizashi. It seems that a lot of the early tachi fittings got reused
> in various ways - could it be that
> a lot of these pieces got "recycled" into wakizashi one way or another,
> hence the large number of early tsuba that have
> the kozuka ana?.
>
> donning the asbestos underwear...
>
> rkg
> (Richard George)
>
> >Hi,
> >Just time for a partial answer. From early koshirae I have seen, katana
>are mounted with kogai only, kozuka and kogai, or neither. I have not seen
>a katana mounted with only a kozuka.
> >
> >Wakizashi are very commonly mounted with only a kozuka, but are also seen
>with kozuka and kogai.
> >
> >The two files in the nihontostudy website File section include columns to

>Koshirae catalog.
> >
> >We see a fair number of 8+ cm tsuba around with a kozuka ana cut in
>them... were they really big wakizashi tsuba, were katana mounted with
>kozuka only at some point or was the ana used for a kogai, despite the
>kozuka shape? I don't know. There is one wakizashi koshirae in the spread
>sheet with an 8.6 cm tsuba, so that might be the explanation.
> >
> >I'll come back to this later.
> >
> >Jim

> > Presence of kogai and kozuka ana are maybe part of the

> > normally have both kozuka and kogai ana or either
> > while wakizashi tsuba normally only have a kozuka ana.
> > Although there are numerous exceptions; small sukashi
> > tsuba which to my eye are obviously for a wakizashi
> > based on size not uncommonly have both. Also many
> > of the very early tosho and katchushi tsuba had

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: katana vs wakizashi
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Richard, Looks like a kozuka-ana to me. The shape of the ana would be more indicative of a kogai rather than the size. Some early stuff with what can be
messages.messageBody:
Hi Richard,

Looks like a kozuka-ana to me. The shape of the ana would be more indicative
of a kogai rather than the size. Some early stuff with what can be taken as
ubu-ana can be either very large or very small. Ko-Mino kogai come in a wild
variety of sizes including pencil thin ones.

Gordon
-----Original Message-----
From: Richard George [mailto:rkg@...]
Sent: Friday, April 25, 2003 2:18 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: katana vs wakizashi


Hi,

Could it be that a some of these "uchigatana sized" tsuba got flipped
over and the kogai ana used for kozuka ana?

I have one piece where the side where most of the banging is around the
nakago ana would iply the hitsu ana was for a kozuka, but
from the shape the ana itself kind of looks like it might have been for
a kogai, and there is some banging on the other side
that looks like they originally did on these pieces - check out:

http://home.teleport.com/~rkg/photos/tsuba/tosho3_front_small.JPG
http://home.teleport.com/~rkg/photos/tsuba/tosho3_back_small.JPG

Another couple of explanations I'd posit is that perhaps there were a
LOT more uchigatana
that weren't katana length or that perhaps people were turning their
uchigatana into
wakizashi via shortening when it became the rage to have a
wakizashi. It seems that a lot of the early tachi fittings got reused
in various ways - could it be that
a lot of these pieces got "recycled" into wakizashi one way or another,
hence the large number of early tsuba that have
the kozuka ana?.

donning the asbestos underwear...

rkg
(Richard George)

>Hi,
>Just time for a partial answer. From early koshirae I have seen, katana
are mounted with kogai only, kozuka and kogai, or neither. I have not seen
a katana mounted with only a kozuka.
>
>Wakizashi are very commonly mounted with only a kozuka, but are also seen
with kozuka and kogai.
>
>The two files in the nihontostudy website File section include columns to
indicate the kozuka and kogai configuration for each mounting in the Katana
Koshirae catalog.
>
>We see a fair number of 8+ cm tsuba around with a kozuka ana cut in
them... were they really big wakizashi tsuba, were katana mounted with
kozuka only at some point or was the ana used for a kogai, despite the
kozuka shape? I don't know. There is one wakizashi koshirae in the spread
sheet with an 8.6 cm tsuba, so that might be the explanation.
>
>I'll come back to this later.
>
>Jim
>
>
> Ken -
>
> Presence of kogai and kozuka ana are maybe part of the
> story. I asked Jim a similar question and as I understood
> his reply (perhaps he will elaborate); katana tsuba
> normally have both kozuka and kogai ana or either
> while wakizashi tsuba normally only have a kozuka ana.
> Although there are numerous exceptions; small sukashi
> tsuba which to my eye are obviously for a wakizashi
> based on size not uncommonly have both. Also many
> of the very early tosho and katchushi tsuba had
> only one (many had been added later). I hope I haven't
> done too much damage to what Jim had said. I'm sure
> he will fill in the blanks.
>
> Rich
>
>[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
>
>

>nihontostudy-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: katana vs wakizashi
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, FWIW, the data in my spreadsheet and the dat file that Rich made from it comes from ca. late Muromachi to early Edo period mounts. I think that katana
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
FWIW, the data in my spreadsheet and the dat file that Rich made from it comes from ca. late Muromachi to early Edo period mounts.

I think that katana and wakizashi with both kozuka and kogai is the more formal arrangement.

I see the katana with neither (kozuka or kogai) as the likely battle setup, or with kogai only, depending on rank. Kozuka only for wakizashi. No proof for that, though.

Jim


Jim, Ken and all -

Could it be that we're seeing the double ana katana tsuba/single
ana wakizashi tsuba for the more "formal" Edo period mounts and
that the others are for battle mounts or perhaps earlier
pre-Edo tsuba or maybe "merchants" sword tsuba where such
formality wasn't observed? Just a thought.

Rich
------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm
http://home.earthlink.net/~steinrl/nihonto.htm
------------------------------------------------------------



Yahoo! Groups Sponsor

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: factory plate
messages.msgSnippet: Ken, I don t think that the article on iron plate is on my site, just on Rich s.  It might be buried in my Q&A page text. I have seen a couple of copper or
messages.messageBody:
Ken,
I don't think that the article on iron plate is on my site, just on Rich's. It might be buried in my Q&A page text.

I have seen a couple of copper or brass plates that appeared to be folded, but I think that's pretty unusual (and I'm not even sure about those). I think that the earlier ones were just hammered out into a plate without folding. Both earlier and later pieces were cast to shape. Metallurgists can identify casting vs. hammering vs. a combination of the two in copper alloy artifacts by microscopic examination of cross sections. I'm not aware of any reliable way to tell from just looking at the finished piece.

Jim
A follow question after reading Jim's article on
"factory plate", I would assume then that evidence of
folding would be one clue to look for in dating a
piece (but not the only clue)? Does this apply to
other metals as well such as copper? Thanks.

Ken


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: katana vs wakizashi
messages.msgSnippet: Hi, Just time for a partial answer.  From early koshirae I have seen, katana are mounted with kogai only, kozuka and kogai, or neither.  I have not seen a
messages.messageBody:
Hi,
Just time for a partial answer. From early koshirae I have seen, katana are mounted with kogai only, kozuka and kogai, or neither. I have not seen a katana mounted with only a kozuka.

Wakizashi are very commonly mounted with only a kozuka, but are also seen with kozuka and kogai.

The two files in the nihontostudy website File section include columns to indicate the kozuka and kogai configuration for each mounting in the Katana Koshirae catalog.

We see a fair number of 8+ cm tsuba around with a kozuka ana cut in them... were they really big wakizashi tsuba, were katana mounted with kozuka only at some point or was the ana used for a kogai, despite the kozuka shape? I don't know. There is one wakizashi koshirae in the spread sheet with an 8.6 cm tsuba, so that might be the explanation.

I'll come back to this later.

Jim


Ken -

Presence of kogai and kozuka ana are maybe part of the
story. I asked Jim a similar question and as I understood
his reply (perhaps he will elaborate); katana tsuba
normally have both kozuka and kogai ana or either
while wakizashi tsuba normally only have a kozuka ana.
Although there are numerous exceptions; small sukashi
tsuba which to my eye are obviously for a wakizashi
based on size not uncommonly have both. Also many
of the very early tosho and katchushi tsuba had
only one (many had been added later). I hope I haven't
done too much damage to what Jim had said. I'm sure
he will fill in the blanks.

Rich

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: katana vs wakizashi
messages.msgSnippet: Sorry had 1 more question from a previous thread.  How is it determined when a tsuba is for a katana or for a wakizashi?  Is it soley based on the presence or
messages.messageBody:
Sorry had 1 more question from a previous thread. How
is it determined when a tsuba is for a katana or for a
wakizashi? Is it soley based on the presence or lack
of a kogai/kozuka ana? How are they viewed when the
ana's are filled in?

Thanks.
Ken

messages.subject: factory plate
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I have recently acquired Haynes catalog #1 and was reading the very nice intro as well as tsuba descriptions.  Could someone fill me in a little more
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

I have recently acquired Haynes catalog #1 and was
reading the very nice intro as well as tsuba
descriptions. Could someone fill me in a little more
about "factory plates". Where these just cast blanks?
Any history would be greatly appreciated. Thanks.

Ken

messages.subject: Re: Thin Tsurumaru Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Jinsoo - A tsuba of very similar design is shown on page 3 of Hawley s Tsubas in Southern California. It is signed Bushu something (the mei is legible, just I
messages.messageBody:
Jinsoo -

A tsuba of very similar design is shown on page 3
of Hawley's Tsubas in Southern California. It is
signed Bushu something (the mei is legible, just
I can't read it all). Perhaps someone with better
Kanji skills than I (that's almost everyone :-)
who has the book can translate the rest for you.

Rich

Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

messages.subject: Thin Tsurumaru Tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Gentlemen, I d like to get any advice for this crane tsuba. It has chocolate color (very smooth surface and slightly dark red) and size is big, 9.1 cm X 8.8 cm
messages.messageBody:
Gentlemen,

I'd like to get any advice for this crane tsuba. It has chocolate
color (very smooth surface and slightly dark red) and size is big, 9.1
cm X 8.8 cm but quite thin, only 3.0mm thickness.

http://nihontobook.homestead.com/files/tsuba/tsurumaru.html

Any guess?

Jinsoo
